entry.title: Christmas Recovery Resilience Retreat
entry.content:
2nd - 5th December 2024

The festive period is a magical time of year, but it is also a time of excess. Trying to maintain a sober or more moderate lifestyle can feel impossible! Have you been told your drinking or drug use is getting out of control? Has recreational turned dysfunctional and you’re not sure what to do about it? Perhaps you’ve had years of sobriety but keep relapsing. Let us help you break the cycle.

Strengthen your defences and escape to Devon for a four-day Recovery Resilience Retreat. An intensive retreat, for men and women, to support abstinence, sobriety or help you to maintain a more moderate lifestyle during the festive season & beyond.

Lantern’s Recovery Resilience Retreat is designed for individuals seeking to manage and overcome problematic alcohol and/or substance use. Over the 4-day recovery retreat you will immerse yourself in specialist psychotherapy sessions specifically designed to provide practical tools and strategies for lasting recovery. By the end of the retreat, you will have developed personalised action plans, and gained valuable skills to manage addictive or problematic behaviours.

Unmanaged alcohol and substance use is complex and whatever stage you are in your recovery journey the retreat will be able to offer the perfect springboard for you to take back control, step out of the shame and move forward into a happy and more fulfilling future.  Invest in yourself and give yourself the best chance for success in 2025 by joining us for some intensive therapy for both your mind and body by releasing trauma past and present. Places are limited to seven per retreat, allowing you to feel safe and supported in an intimate setting.

By bringing together intensive group psychotherapy sessions with Somatic Yoga and Fire & Ice therapy the Recovery Resilience Retreat is the only retreat of its kind currently available!

Intensive Therapy Sessions

Janie our in-house psychotherapist, specialises in substance misuse and trauma recovery.  prior to joining the retreat Janie will contact you to discuss your current level of use and where you are aiming to get to. Janie & our team of specialist practitioners will provide you with a supportive space where you can focus on your recovery surrounded by like minded individuals.

Yoga & Recovery

Do you use drugs or alcohol to self-medicate? Yoga supports the treatment & recovery of trauma and addiction by restoring the disconnection that occurs due to substance abuse and traumatic events. Perhaps you use to avoid feeling difficult emotions or just to help you cope with a stressful lifestyle? Overtime you avoid processing emotions and so when you stop self-medicating it can feel very overwhelming and fill you with anxiety, dread and paranoia. Yoga reduces anxiety and research has shown that yoga has been an effective way of reducing and in some cases eliminating symptoms of PTSD and anxiety.

“Fire & Ice” Therapy

Wim Hof has advocated the benefits of cold-water therapy for addiction recovery and rehab centres worldwide took notice and so did we!

At the Recovery Resilience Retreat we have taken this to the next level, by combining thermalist therapy, cold-water therapy and breath work. You will be guided through your sessions by Sara, the only combined Wim Hoff and thermalist therapy qualified practitioner globally. Merging cold water, the warmth of the sauna and deep breath work, your body will efficiently burn off cortisol (the stress chemical your body produces) reducing stress and anxiety, leaving your mind clearer, your body revitalised and emotionally stronger and empowered.

The retreat is not a rehab or detox programme, rather a safe space where you can learn & heal surrounded by the beautiful Devonshire countryside. The retreat offers hot tubs, a sauna, fire pit & peaceful places for reflection. Enjoy the stunning rural location and nature. Dine on local, nutritious meals, freshly prepared by our professional catering team. The accommodation comprises of luxury, private double bedrooms in either a 16 century barn conversion or within the west wing of the manor house.

If you have any questions about this retreat please call us on 01903 953766
or contact us and a member of the team will be happy to help.

entry.title: The Relationship Recovery Retreat
entry.content:
11th – 14th November 2024

The Relationship Recovery Retreat is a transformative journey designed specifically for women overcoming the impact of difficult, unhealthy, and unhappy relationships. Over four days of trauma-informed sessions, you will reconnect with your intuition, explore personal blocks and boundaries, and rebuild self-trust and confidence.

Led by Janie, the resident In-House Psychotherapist specialising in trauma recovery, this retreat aims to empower women to break free from the shadows of damaging relationships and reclaim their strength and independence. Through guided activities, reflective exercises, and supportive group discussions, you will:

  • Reconnect with your inner voice and intuition.
  • Explore and overcome personal blocks and boundaries.
  • Rebuild self-trust and confidence.
  • Gain a profound understanding of the impact of damaging relationships.
  • Equip yourself with tools to support your long-term recovery and well-being.

Reclaim your voice, make confident decisions, and foster a deep sense of self-awareness. By the end of the retreat you will leave with a renewed sense of empowerment, clarity, and an actionable personal intuition plan to guide your ongoing recovery and personal growth.

Set in the incredible Devonshire countryside, the beautiful venue offers hot tubs, a sauna, a fire pit, and peaceful places for reflection. Enjoy the stunning rural location and immerse yourself in nature. Explore the ancient woods, meditate by the lake, or lose yourself in the stunning views over the rolling hills.

 

During your stay, dine on locally sourced, nutritious meals, freshly prepared by our catering team. The accommodation comprises of luxury, private double bedrooms in either a 16th-century barn conversion or within the west wing of the manor house.

Places are limited to a maximum of seven per retreat to ensure time and space in an intimate setting.

Meet the team…

Janie – Host & Psychotherapist

Janie is the resident In-House Psychotherapist, specialising in trauma recovery. Janie is the resident In-House Psychotherapist, specialising in trauma recovery. Her mission is to empower women to break free from the shadows of unhealthy relationships and to reclaim their strength and independence.
Throughout this retreat, participants will explore the underlying dynamics in abusive relationships and, more importantly, how to break free from these patterns. The goal is to provide a profound understanding of the impact of unhealthy relationships and equip participants with the tools to support their long-term recovery and well-being.

Throughout this retreat, participants will explore the underlying dynamics in abusive relationships and, more importantly, how to break free from these patterns. The goal is to provide a profound understanding of the impact of unhealthy relationships and equip participants with the tools to support their long-term recovery and well-being.

Whether they have endured a challenging long-term relationship, a painful separation or divorce, or are currently navigating a dysfunctional or unhappy relationship, Janie is here to guide them on their journey from surviving to thriving.

During the retreat, Janie will lead group therapy sessions designed to boost confidence and rebuild resilience. The sessions will explore the following areas:

  • Attachment Theory: Understanding the bonds that shape relationships.
  • Identifying Narcissistic Behaviour: Recognising the signs and breaking free.
  • Cognitive Distortions: Challenging and changing harmful thought patterns.
  • Mindfulness: Cultivating awareness and presence for healing.
  • Cognitive Behaviour Therapy (CBT): Developing strategies for emotional well-being.

Before joining the retreat, participants will have an online meeting with Janie to discuss their goals and complete an initial assessment. At the conclusion of the retreat, there will be a final session to consolidate progress and plan their continued journey of self-empowerment.

Together, this retreat aims to transform participants' experiences from mere survival to a powerful journey of personal growth and resilience. LetJoin us for this empowering retreat and take the first step towards your healing and empowerment journey's take the first step towards healing and empowerment.

Vanessa - Yoganess

Yoga Teacher, Vanessa Bourne (“Ness”) has been helping people improve their lives with yoga for the past 18 years. Ness teaches her clients how to incorporate the ancient practices of gentle movement, meditation & effective breathing into her client’s everyday lives to help them feel better by giving them a greater sense of control over their own lives. The goal is to build awareness, self-regulation of the nervous system & deepening self-understanding, all these skills lead to better mental health & well-being. Ness incorporates up to date, evidence based, practical health information to further improve outcomes for her clients.

Ness is Hatha Yoga qualified with British School & has completed additional training with Kristine Weber, a leading world authority on the neuroscientific benefits of Subtle® Yoga (a form of somatic yoga). Somatic yoga offers a holistic & gentle approach to trauma recovery, addressing both physical & emotional aspects of healing. By fostering a deeper connection to the body, reducing stress, & promoting mindful awareness, it supports individuals in their journey towards recovery & well-being.

Ness continues to develop her yoga practice with the Subtle Yoga Resilience Society & currently specialises in specific subjects such as Yoga for Brain Health, Enhanced Trauma Recovery, Menopause, & the Neuroscience of Yoga.  Ness’s wealth of experience & extensive training combined with her great sense of humour & empathy allows her to deliver effective trauma informed, safe & effective yoga practices, whilst simultaneously making her clients feel at ease.

Sara - Devon Sauna Hub

Thermalist & Breathwork Therapy “Fire & Ice”

Sara, is currently the only woman in the UK jointly qualified as a Thermalist Instructor & a level 2 Wim Hoff Method Instructor.  Combining these specialist areas is unique & considered to be the highest form of qualifications currently available for Thermalist & Breathwork combined therapy, globally!

Thermalist Therapy is essentially Hot & Cold Therapy – moving your body between hot elements (sauna) & cold elements (cold water) reconnecting body & mind & keeping them in their optimum state. The healthy stress of the cold & the heat navigated by the breath, builds your cells stronger, increases your metabolism & strengthens your nervous system. Our body’s natural ‘fight -or- flight’ response, releases high levels of cortisol (the stress chemical) into the bloodstream & when this is left unmanaged results in our bodies & brains becoming unbalanced. Combining the shock of the cold-water therapy with the release of calming chemicals in our body from the breathwork & sauna, Sara can restore your mind & body’s natural balance, leaving you feeling relaxed, revigorated & recentred.

entry.title: Trauma-Informed Care
entry.content:
OVERVIEW:

This training provides a comprehensive understanding of Trauma-Informed Care. We explore the principles and practices of Trauma-Informed Care, focusing on recognising and responding to the signs and effects of trauma in individuals. Participants will learn how to create a supportive environment that promotes safety, trust, and empowerment, while developing strategies for integrating trauma-informed approaches into their daily interactions and practices.

This course can be adapted for managers and team leaders to include developing and implementing Trauma-Informed policies and procedures.

COURSE TO INCLUDE:

  • What is Trauma-Informed Care?
  • Key principles and practices of Trauma-Informed Care.
  • Recognising signs and symptoms of trauma.
  • Understanding the impact of trauma on physical and psychological health.
  • Strategies for creating a trauma-sensitive environment.
  • Techniques for supporting individuals with trauma histories.

entry.content:
Last updated: Wednesday 25th August 2021.

INTRODUCTION

Lantern Life Ltd. (“we” or “us” or “our”) may use cookies, web beacons, tracking pixels, and other tracking technologies when you visit our website lanternlife.co.uk, including any other media form, media channel, mobile website, or mobile application related or connected thereto (collectively, the “Site”) to help customise the Site and improve your experience. 

We reserve the right to make changes to this Cookie Policy at any time and for any reason. We will alert you about any changes by updating the “Last Updated” date of this Cookie Policy. Any changes or modifications will be effective immediately upon posting the updated Cookie Policy on the Site, and you waive the right to receive specific notice of each such change or modification. 

You are encouraged to periodically review this Cookie Policy to stay informed of updates. You will be deemed to have been made aware of, will be subject to, and will be deemed to have accepted the changes in any revised Cookie Policy by your continued use of the Site after the date such revised Cookie Policy is posted.

USE OF COOKIES

A “cookie” is a string of information which assigns you a unique identifier that we store on your computer. Your browser then provides that unique identifier to use each time you submit a query to the Site. We use cookies on the Site to, among other things, keep track of services you have used, record registration information, record your user preferences, keep you logged into the Site, facilitate purchase procedures, and track the pages you visit. Cookies help us understand how the Site is being used and improve your user experience.

TYPES OF COOKIES

The following types of cookies may be used when you visit the Site:

Our Cookies

Our cookies are “first-party cookies”, and can be either permanent or temporary. These are necessary cookies, without which the Site won't work properly or be able to provide certain features and functionalities. Some of these may be manually disabled in your browser, but may affect the functionality of the Site.

Personalise Cookies

Personalise cookies are used to recognise repeat visitors to the Site. We use these cookies to record your browsing history, the pages you have visited, and your settings and preferences each time you visit the Site.

Site Management Cookies

Site management cookies are used to maintain your identity or session on the Site so that you are not logged off unexpectedly, and any information you enter is retained from page to page. These cookies cannot be turned off individually, but you can disable all cookies in your browser.

Third-Party Cookies

Third-party cookies may be place on your computer when you visit the Site by companies that run certain services we offer. These cookies allow the third parties to gather and track certain information about you. These cookies can be manually disabled in your browser.

CONTROL OF COOKIES

Most browsers are set to accept cookies by default. However, you can remove or reject cookies in your browser’s settings. Please be aware that such action could affect the availability and functionality of the Site. For more information on how to control cookies, check your browser or device’s settings for how you can control or reject cookies.

OTHER TRACKING TECHNOLOGIES

In addition to cookies, we may use web beacons, pixel tags, and other tracking technologies on the Site to help customise the Site and improve your experience. A “web beacon” or “pixel tag” is tiny object or image embedded in a web page or email. They are used to track the number of users who have visited particular pages and viewed emails, and acquire other statistical data. They collect only a limited set of data, such as a cookie number, time and date of page or email view, and a description of the page or email on which they reside. Web beacons and pixel tags cannot be declined. However, you can limit their use by controlling the cookies that interact with them.

PRIVACY POLICY

For more information about how we use information collected by cookies and other tracking technologies, please refer to our Privacy Policy lanternlife.co.uk/privacy-policy posted on the Site. This Cookie Policy is part of and is incorporated into our Privacy Policy. By using the Site, you agree to be bound by this Cookie Policy and our Privacy Policy.

entry.title: Vicarious Trauma
entry.content:
OVERVIEW:

This training is an in-depth look at what Vicarious Trauma means and how it can impact on people in the workplace.  We learn about the signs and symptoms of Vicarious Trauma and apply this to how we can manage it as individuals, including how we advocate for ourselves in a team, how to address our work/life balance and how to apply healthy coping strategies.

COURSE TO INCLUDE:

  • What is vicarious trauma?
  • Physical and psychological affects
  • How do I know when I am affected by it?
  • What can we do to manage this as a team?
  • Personal Plan
